review.title: Decisional Processes with Boolean Neural Network: the Emergence of Mental Schemes
review.abstract: Human decisional processes result from the employment of selected quantities of relevant information, generally synthesized from environmental incoming data and stored memories. Their main goal is the production of an appropriate and adaptive response to a cognitive or behavioral task. Different strategies of response production can be adopted, among which haphazard trials, formation of mental schemes and heuristics. In this paper, we propose a model of Boolean neural network that incorporates these strategies by recurring to global optimization strategies during the learning session. The model characterizes as well the passage from an unstructured/chaotic attractor neural network typical of data-driven processes to a faster one, forward-only and representative of schema-driven processes. Moreover, a simplified version of the Iowa Gambling Task (IGT) is introduced in order to test the model. Our results match with experimental data and point out some relevant knowledge coming from psychological domain.

sections.heading: 5. Conclusion and future perspectives
sections.text: We have presented preliminary results of applying a Boolean model of neural networks to relevant cognitive strategies involved in decision-making tasks. Currently, only mental schematics have been studied, and the choice of such formalization is due to the possibilities offered by Boolean neural networks in terms of robustness, simple simulation, and easy generation of samples for data adaptation; the model appears to capture the most relevant psychological knowledge in terms of scope. By moving from an unstructured neural attractor network to a faster forward-looking network, it also applies to learning studies on the complexity of tasks and the number of cognitive resources employed. As defined, mental schematics will lead to fast and adaptive cognitive strategies of behavioral response. In terms of model adaptation, the behavior of our network on the simplified version of IGT will yield results qualitatively comparable to those of humans.
